<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of consumer_thread:
```c
static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (!counter)
		metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
	counter--;
	metal_condition_signal(&nfull_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function consumer_thread:
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
	metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The call metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock) passes addresses of synchronization objects that will be modified by the wait operation (condition and mutex). Rule 8.13 requires pointers to be const-qualified where possible; here the pointed-to objects must be mutable (and the function API will expect non-const pointers), so using non-const pointers is appropriate.
